data.title: Syntax theme color control for comments / documentation conventions
"Blotchy" Theme Background
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra, 10.12.3 (16D32)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use the built-in Solarized Light theme.
2. Open a new window.
3. Observe that the background color is not consistent. (See screenshot. EDIT: Note that I added the dashed lines to make the distinction slightly more clear.) This isn't a theme issue, as the [theme clearly claims the color should be #FDF6E3](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/theme-solarized-light/themes/Solarized-light.tmTheme#L13).

![vscode-theme](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/156557/23039585/992743e4-f453-11e6-9b12-81380d89163c.png)


Even more oddly, I get different results on each of my 3 monitors: on my Retina screen, no problems. On my largest external screen, my main screen, I get the attached. On my 3rd monitor, I see the issue, but the incorrect color is #FDF6E4. Note that the 2 external screens are not retina.

I didn't look in detail through all themes, but a quick glance seemed to indicate at least the Red theme was also affected.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-09T00:26:45.394Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-icontheme-nomo-dark|be5invis|1.2.5|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.3.4|
|LogFileHighlighter|emilast|1.1.1|
|vscode-great-icons|emmanuelbeziat|1.1.44|
|output-colorizer|IBM|0.0.10|
|vscode-icon-theme|jtlowe|1.4.0|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.10.1|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.7.0|
|material-icon-theme|PKief|1.3.3|
|trailing-spaces|shardulm94|0.2.11|
|perforce|slevesque|1.0.0|
|markdown-pdf|yzane|0.1.6|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Right click a json file, Open with > VS Code
2. Nothing happens. If VS Code is not running, it will start, but not open the json file.

data.title: Custom code snippet not working in react
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-09T00:26:45.394Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.3.9600
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|0.10.18|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a .js file
2. Create a custom code snippet inside of javascript.json such as the one below:
```
"Target Blank": {
	"prefix": "_b",
	"body": [
		"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" "
	],
	"description": "Prevent new tab from having access to original window."
}
```
3. In a react javascript file with the .js extension, inside of the
```
render() { 
     return ( 
          <THIS AREA> 
     ) 
}
```
try to type a custom made code snippet (_b). It won't work. 
3. Outside of  return area type _b. It will work. (inserts _blank" rel="noopener noreferrer").

data.title: Wrong type is accepted
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 Enterprise

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  By creating a service, then try to send a post method i.e. :
     http.post('/the_url', parameters, **options**)
2.  I set wrong **options** parameter like this: 
    const headers = new Headers();
    headers.append('Content-Type', 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded');
    http.post('the_url', parameters, **headers**) instead of sending new RequestOptions({ headers: headers }) there.

The post method when uses just headers as option does not work and it does not complain about wrong type and this is really hard to detect because there is no errors or warning at compilation time or runtime. I guess the IDE must show a warning otherwise the goal of why it was created (script typed) stop making sense I guess. It is really helpful to have that kind of support at compilation time.

When I replaced headers by RequestOptions({ headers: headers }) it worked properly. 

It would be great if could consider it.

Thanks in advance,

Luis.

data.title: "No Project" reported by TSServer.js. Autocompleting doesn't works.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: ArchLinux

I tried to restart, reload etc.. Nothings help. I can't say how to reproduce it.

Workspace:
[test.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/781252/test.zip)

Logs from DevTools:
```
Error processing request. No Project.
Error: No Project.
    at Object.ThrowNoProject (/opt/visual-studio-code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js:6146:23)
    at IOSession.Session.getFileAndProjectWorker (/opt/visual-studio-code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js:68162:42)
    at IOSession.Session.getFileAndProjectWithoutRefreshingInferredProjects (/opt/visual-studio-code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js:68156:29)
    at IOSession.Session.getCodeFixes (/opt/visual-studio-code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js:68558:31)
    at Session.handlers.ts.createMap._a.(anonymous function) (/opt/visual-studio-code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js:67627:61)
    at IOSession.Session.executeCommand (/opt/visual-studio-code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js:68664:28)
    at IOSession.Session.onMessage (/opt/visual-studio-code/resources/app/extensions/typescript/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js:68684:35)

    at Interface.emit (events.js:188:7)
```

- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.3.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|openwhisk|AndrewTrice|0.0.3|
|swift|Kasik96|0.0.2|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.11|
|jshint|dbaeumer|0.10.15|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.5|
|Scala|itryapitsin|0.1.7|
|Angular1|johnpapa|0.1.16|
|ionic1-snippets|justinjames|1.0.1|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.51|
|dust|nemesarial|0.0.1|
|nativescript-xml-snippets|tsvetan-ganev|1.0.4|
|cordova-tools|vsmobile|1.2.5|
|nativescript-ng2-snippets|wwwalkerrun|1.2.0|
|Material-theme|zhuangtongfa|1.0.3|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open any Markdown file with extension `md` foo.md
2. Click the preview icon on the top right 

Preview can't take the whole editor window space, it cuts off half size both vertical and horizontal in editor and I need to scroll

data.title: Consider a different color for meta.preprocessor in Dark / Dark+

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Currently, the Dark and Dark+ themes highlight the `meta.preprocessor` scope (`#if`, `#else`, `#end`...) like this:

![](http://i.imgur.com/pMgvWq6.png)

That's the same color that keywords use, which makes for bad readability.

That's why we currently employ a hack in the Haxe extension's grammar - we use the `punctuation.definition.tag` scope to get a nicely distuingishable, grey color for conditional compilation statements.

Compare this with the previous image:

![](http://i.imgur.com/zILClf0.png)

To me, this is significantly more readable.

Other language grammars that use `meta.preprocessor` include C# ([Example](http://i.imgur.com/OeuRRIy.png)). C++ [only uses `meta.preprocessor` for the actual define](http://i.imgur.com/6QuffnG.png), but not `#ifdef` and friends.

data.title: Allow to create multi-cursor with keyboard

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.0 - insider
- OS Version: Windows

-- Sorry for the English, I used Google Translator --

Allow me to place multiple cursors by navigating with the arrow keys.

Like this extension [multi-cursor-plus](https://atom.io/packages/multi-cursor-plus) of Atom. Press `alt + x` to highlight a cursor, use the arrow keys to scroll to the next location you want (by pressing the `alt `key), and press again.

If I wanted to take some specific cursor, I'll enter the arrows to the location and press `alt + x` again.

![68747470733a2f2f7261772e67697468756275736572636f6e74656e742e636f6d2f6b616e6b61726973746f2f61746f6d2d6d756c74692d637572736f722d706c75732f6769662f73686f77636173652e676966](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19866231/23032826/ff22e12c-f45c-11e6-8b41-0263fd185dbb.gif)

data.title: Ubuntu: Can't save / create any files
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: ubuntu 16.04 LTS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Download latest install, install
2. Open VS Code
3. Open folder (/home/josh/projects/myawesomeproject)
4. Try to modify or save anything (or try to debug).

Expected result:
Saves / creates the document

Actual result:

Edit:
Failed to save 'LICENSE.txt': A system error occurred (EACCES: permission denied, open '/home/josh/Projects/myawesomeproject/LICENSE.txt')

Create:
A system error occured (EACCES: permission denied, open '/home/josh/Projects/myawesomeproject/testfile')

data.title: add support for global options in tasks.json for tasks with locally defined commands
data.body:
It would be helpful to be able to define globally applied options to tasks in tasks.json, even for tasks that define their own command locally. I am told this is currently not supported; if a task defines its command locally then it will not inherit any global options.

I am proposing that global options are applied to all tasks defined in tasks.json, with the following rules. This is described from the key/value standpoint of the "env" parameter, but the same logic would apply to "cwd" as well:

1. if any key is defined globally, and no override of that key is defined locally to a task, the global value is applied
2. if any key is defined locally, and no global definition of that key exists, the local value is applied
3. if any key is defined both globally and locally, the local value of that key "overrides" the global, and is applied

1. Open VSCode (`code .` anywhere)
2. It shows the welcome screen. Uncheck "Show welcome page on startup"
3. Close VSCode.
4. GOTO 1

data.title: Proposal: Change order of completions of CSS properties.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
When I write css properties, sometimes I feel annoyed at the order of completion.

For example, I type `borr` and Tab with the intentention of being converted to `border-radius:`,
but it is converted to `border-bottom-left-radius:`.
I think it's better to be converted to `border-radius` in this case.

I think this is because completions are ordered by natural order of property name.

So, I think it's better for completions to be sorted by `(numberOfChunksSeparatedByHyphen, nameOfProperty)`.

By this,
border-bottom-left-radius -> (4, "border-bottom-left-radius")
border-radius -> (2, "border-radius")
so, border-radius is given priority,
and in other cases, shorter properties are given priority.
